description:
This is my new favorite French restaurant. My favorite part about it is the fact that in the front of the restaurant you have nice slow music, and as you go to the back there's mariachi playing. Yes!

The food was really good. Yes!
author: Smeraldine R.

description:
A and I recently came for dinner at Cocotte after having not dined there for 2 years and the food was just as good as remembered. We made a reservation for late on Saturday night with an hour of lead time. We arrived 10 minutes early and were sat at a high top in the bar area. Cocotte is not a big restaurant at all so the bar area and the dining room are pretty much one in the same. However, we were not given menus for 10 minutes and it became very clear that our server was actually the bartender who had to come out from behind the bar to take our order and check on us. This resulted in a lot of delays both in actually getting menus, placing our order and getting the bill. It wasn't a big deal since we weren't in a rush and did eventually get service but my suggestion to the restaurant is to actually have a waiter (not the bartender) assigned to that table.

I got a very nice glass of Bordeaux and A had a great beer that he hadn't tried from Headlands Brewing. Definitely a small, but mighty, alcohol selection. Having been here before and remembering how good the food was, we both got exactly what we ordered the previous time. A got the Beef Wellington which was delicious, if not a smaller portion. He wasn't full when he was done but since you can never find Beef Wellington on a menu, he was happy. I got the Coq Au Vin which was just as hearty and delicious as I remembered. Since mine was a really generous size, A was able to have quite a bit.

We originally weren't going to get dessert but after watching other tables and seeing what they were getting, we decided to splurge. We had a very hard time deciding from their large list full of particularly tempting items but ultimately settled on the Banana Creme Brûlée and it was OUT OF THIS WORLD. Seriously, it is a must-order.

All in all, Cocotte is an awesome, cozy spot for some good French food. The prices are fine and the food is delicious. Giving it four stars based on our service experience this time (no fault of the bartender) though I could see it being a five-star experience if you are physically dining at the bar or have an actual table in the dining room.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Great for date night. Cozy and atmospheric.

We strolled in without a reservation at 645 on a Thursday before our 8 pm showtime at the Masonic. They gave us a table no problem. We enjoyed all the cocottes on offer (all vegetarian, though they have veggie entrees as well) and two glasses of excellent wine, and were on our way.
author: A K.

description: This small little restaurant is a real charmer if you want a fancy meal with your  significant other. The staff there are friendly and personal. As soon as I walked in I was introduced by the owner and the head chef. While enjoying my meal more people came, and the owner seemed to know most of them on a first name basis. I recommend the beef wellington. Delicious meat baked inside a puff pastry. They don't have much of cocktail selection, but plenty of wine. Parking is nightmare in the area, better off taking muni. Welcome to wonderful French cuisine.
author: Joel G.

description: Had a dinner here with a yelp employee and I am yelping this - nice sugar control for creme brûlée and above the average for everything else , the timing was bit bad for the main courses cuz we waited for bit long
author: Lulu Y.

description:
What a charming, little French restaurant. Although parking was a bit tricky, we eventually made it here for our 6pm reservations on a Friday evening. It wasn't busy yet when we arrived, but others soon trickled in. If you want an extra special and romantic dinner date, make reservations for their curtain-enclosed table for two --very intimate!

We started off with some complimentary bread with an anchovy and basil olive oil. This pairing was amazing and so yummy. I loved how the breads were a rustic sourdough that were the perfect slices and size to start us off. We also each had a glass of wine (a red and a white) from the HH menu for $8 each.

For our main courses, we shared the Beef Filet Wellington ($34) and the Half Chicken ($15 on HH/$21) with Shishito Peppers. I was most eager to try the beef wellington, which was great but not quite memorable. It comes in two palm-size slices of pastry-wrapped tenderloin alongside a bone marrow. If you're into bone marrow, this dish comes with it all. Unfortunately, the boyfriend and I don't find the hype in bone marrow as I had the spoonful of fatty juices from it. It's still delicious though. As for the chicken, it came with four pieces. The flavor was there, but a bit dry. We definitely needed the sauces to dip in, which we found rather flavorless as well.

The highlight of our meal might have had to be the shishito peppers. They were incredibly flavorful and had such a killer spice to it. There was one that burned me for a few minutes. Trust me, I can handle spicy but that pepper was insanely hot!

We left fully stuffed and thoroughly enjoyed our meal. The cozy restaurant has a lovely ambiance and solid food, although not quite memorable in taste.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Such a cute little neighborhood gem! I love the small size and feel of this restaurant. Perfect for date night.

Like others have reviewed, the Beef Wellington with bone marrow was outstanding. The Frisée Salad with crispy pork belly and poached egg had me craving for more. Everything was perfectly seasoned and beautifully presented. The wines by-the-glass were decent and paired nicely with dinner.

I would definitely return.
author: Martin S.

description:
I had the esteemed pleasure of eating at Cocotte a couple weeks ago with a friend of mine and we had a blast! Not only was the food delicious but, we had an incredible server (french guy) and the chef came out to say a huge thank you. I always appreciate a restaurant where you know whos behind everything...it's a nice touch.

The place was fairly empty as we made a reservation on Yelp pretty late but, they were quick to accommodate. We ended up sharing the chicken and a bottle of burgundy wine. The roasted chicken was perfectly cooked and the earthy wine paired wonderfully. 

Check this place out if you're looking for a great neighborhood restaurant or a nice little first date spot ;)
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Wow.  Just looking for somewhere to eat and we parked on Hyde to look at a restaurant.  We weren't dressed for the place and so we walked around the block and stopped at the place we parked in front of.  Some times you stumble onto a place and the stars align and you step into a culinary delight.  And that is what we found here at Cocotte.  
We sat at the bar and I asked Yuri to recommend a white wine that fit my taste for a sauvignon blanc and voigner.  And he gave me a glass of La Redonne from Jean Luc Colombo's. It was wonderful.  
So I trusted him again with his recommendations and for dinner and I accepted the Beef Wellington and bone marrow with a spinach side that made me completely happy.  It was so wonderful, and this French bistro is a great place to enjoy a dinner on a tree lined street during a beautiful spring day in San Francisco.  Thank you for a wonderful surprise.
author: Robert B.

description: Beef Wellington to die for. We came for a friend's birthday and the food did not disappoint!  Bone marrow appetizer was fabulous, and we basically ordered all the vegetarian cocottes. They were so delicious and the wine selection paired well with all the dishes. An overall extremely memorable night. Service was attentive and fun. We came a bit late to our reservation so we were moved but we still got a good table.
author: Evonne L.

description:
We went here as a part of SF Restaurant week. 

The ambiance is spectacular! The wine bar near the door is quaint and comfortable. Their Spanish wine selections are solid for how small the place is. 

The seating is intimate but enjoyable. 

I started with the Truffle Tremor Goat Cheese Beignet. This was the highlight of the meal! Get this if you can. 

My main course was the Gnocchi. Beware it's a very small portion. It was good not great. Presentation was superb but it was a bit dry. 

The Apple dessert dish was delicious. Savory and an incredible combination of melt in your mouth and crisp. 

We will be back!
author: John A.

description:
Here for a casual Friday date dinner.

Cozy little French restaurant on a quiet street with great ambiance. Great service but we were a little rushed by the servers to leave (~1.5 hrs) because of reservations for the next table, which was fine but might not be ideal if you want to take your time here for dinner.

We came here for the beef Wellington and it certainly did not disappoint (5 stars) - tender meat wrapped in crispy puff pastry accompanied by rich pan sauce and bone marrow. Other dishes we ordered were also consistently good, including Parisan gnocchi (5 stars), coq au vin (4 stars), and shishito pepper (4 stars). Though portions were on the smaller end, they definitely tasted delicious and authentic. Wines here are great as well with generous pours! 

TLDR: great authentic French food, must order beef Wellington and great little cozy spot!
author: Nancy Z.

description:
We all had the Wellington since that was the known item and there was only about 4 entree selection. We also ordered the clams, Brussels sprouts, potatoes. The clams and potatoes are good. The Brussels sprouts were sparse and soggy. 

The beef in the Wellington is good. It comes with a bone marrow. I wish the dish came with some veggies on the side. 

Very good service. Kind chef and wait staff.
author: Gloria T.

description:
I dined here as part of SF Restaurant Week. What a cozy, intimate and hip French spot! Though the dining quarters were a bit tight, the friendly staff and superb wine suggestions and selections more than made up for them. 

To start I had the ahi tuna tartar which, candidly, I would not order again (was not thrilled with the flavor nor the quality). Perhaps I was just jealous of the starter my boyfriend selected - the Truffle Tremor goat cheese beignet. It was phenomenal ! The shake you to your core, scraping every last drop, including the lettuce it was served with, phenomenal. 

My main meal selection was the porc shank osso bucco, which was good though not great. My boyfriend was displeased with the gnocchi he ordered and agreed after tasting mine that the porc shank was the better entree. 

Our desserts were absolutely wonderful! The molten chocolate cake is a must! And my boyfriend absolutely loved the golden apple tarte tatin. 

Overall I can't wait to stop in for another glass of wine and a light bite ! Perhaps even just for the delectable desserts !
author: Rachel P.

description: What a charming, cozy, and authentic French restaurant. I love the fact that they have a prix fixe three course dinner. It made everything so easy for the customers and the chef. Nice selection of French wines. The only thing I would change is the music. The music was definitely beat read the music which gave me a headache. It had nothing to do with French dining. Very loud. Otherwise I would've given it five stars.
author: Tricia Y.

description:
I came here with my friend for a belated celebration of my birthday and this was so much better than my actual birthday meal. 

We got the ahi tuna and it was only okay. I felt like there was too much sauce going on. It really drowned out the flavor of the fish and made everything too salty.

Now the entrees are really where the meal shines. We got the beef wellington with bone marrow and half a chicken with cauliflower au gratin. The meats were all super tender and juicy. The beef wellington was cooked to perfection. The chicken came with 3 different sauces. The pesto was super fresh and was my favorite. The cauliflower au gratin tasted like healthy mashed potatoes with cheese. Definitely a good alternative. The bone marrow was good too. The perfect amount of seasoning and flavoring.

We got the banana creme Brulee for dessert. It was just creme brulee with bananas on top. It was good. I wouldn't say it's fantastic but it's good. It was pretty cheap too for the serving.

My only complaint was that we didn't get anything special for my birthday. Another table had free cake with a candle but I got nothing :( Still, a great meal.
author: Becky H.

description:
I have walked by a million times but never stopped in, that was my mistake. Every part of the dining experience was top notch and incredible. The service and hosts were caring and attentive. The food was unbelievable. We had the beef wellington, coq au vin, mushroom soup, foie gras, and ended with banana creme brûlée and the flourless mint cake.  The bread and tapenade were also wonderful! 

Honestly one of the best meals I have had in a long time. Cocotte has shot up on my list as one of the best places in the city!

I feel lucky to have them near.
author: Jesse K.

description:
Bleck. This place is overrated. WAY TOO EXPENSIVE for what it is. Cramped space, not particularly appealing, disinterested service, mediocre food. Was very disappointed. This is the type of restaurant that could get by if total per person for a meal was about $20 but at $50+/person (without drinks) it's a hard no.

Experience:
Restaurant - kind of dingy. Cold because the whole front opens and they'd left it open even though it was a chilly night. They shut it when we asked but made us feel like we were imposing by even asking. I'd think the host in a sweater and scarf and most of the patrons in jackets wouldve been a tipoff that people were cold.

Seated at bar table even though we had a reservation. The table was too small.

Tartare tacos not good - cocktail sauce flavor.

Gem salad with fried goat cheese balls - good

Potatoes - good
Beets - ok. basic beets. 

Chicken not great - if that's their focus it's lacking. Costco better :(

Molten cake - naaaaaasty. Yeesh. Take this one off the menu.

Gross bathroom - dirty and incorrectly shaped toilet seat so if you have to sit your skin is going to touch toilet; why wasn't that immediately fixed when someone bought the wrong size?

There is no elegance to the food or space. The food all sat heavy. Will never go back.
author: Ryan B.

description: Good food but the chef made an unsolicited, inappropriate, and unprofessional advance on my significant. Hmmm..... I will spare you the details
author: Royal B.

description:
Inept service.  Good food and ambiance, but not enough
Just finished a Valentines Day dinner at Cocotte.  In the middle of dinner the waiter spilled my wife's full glass of red wine over me, providing a robust soaking of my jacket, shirt and trousers. While he apologized (the host, standing nearby showed no concern) he offered to "make it up to me" the next time we dined there.   Not a reduction of the current bill or some real time consideration for their blunder. 
Truly an inept response to spilling wine all over me and costing me an expensive dry cleaning bill. 
      Regretful.
author: Roger S.

description:
It's just sad to have such a positive experience from the past turn so sour in one fell swoop. I visited the restaurant a few years back and received not only a wonderful meal but also friendly service from welcoming staff who assisted me with my take out order. But last week, my partner Ursula (review below) and I attempted to eat in and when we asked for a wheelchair ramp, the man who spoke to us from the restaurant was so needlessly rude that she felt compelled to write a review. She then received a response from the management there that was, frankly, perfunctory at best. 

So, save yourself from potentially turning a pleasant evening into such an unnecessarily nasty one by going elsewhere.
author: Yvette F.

description: My second experience at cocotte was equally, if not better, than my first! The food is amazing and the staff puts everything over the top. Friendly, helpful, goes out of their way. The chef even came out to ask us how everything was. Absolutely amazing dinner...love my local neighborhood restaurant!
author: Kali H.

description:
Cocotte is such a cute and charming restaurant. The food and service is always on point each time I come. I recently went there for a birthday party for 25 people and everything came out beautifully and tasted wonderful. There was a prix-fixe menu and we were able to choose from a few items for each course. They offered some of the standards of a French bistro but the chef adds a different twist to some of his dishes and were all executed beautifully. I was so amazed that for the entire meal, appetizers, entrees, desserts... each course, everyone had their plate at the same time. Now, that is some skillz.
We also happen to meet the chef, Micah and he is one of the most humble and amazing chefs around. 

Thumbs up: amazing food, cozy atmosphere, attentive service
Thumbs down: no street parking
Would I return: oui!!
author: Heidi L.

description:
Intimate but lively French restaurant, just what you'd expect from Hyde street. Friendly and attentive service yet feels like you're deep into Paris somewhere.

Started with the foie gras torchon, it was a bit cold and hard but when it sat for about 10 minutes was amazing. I could have used a better pairing, cherries for it, whatever they had was hard to keep on the toast and bland.

The beef Wellington was quite good, good sharing portion, could have been a tad more tender but overall well executed, light flaky pastry, great sauce.

Broccoli was very flavorful, well prepared. 

Great experience, would definitely recommend and come back again.
author: Inga W.

description: I love this place. The food, service, and wine was perfect. But they forgot to wrap half of our Beef Wellington to go. This was our second time there and I really wanted to give them 5 stars. I know I will next time.
author: Bebe L.

description:
Loved this place. Definitely a little pricey for us but a good date night spot. 

Food was awesome. Some highlights: 
Appetizer-beef tartar & foie gras tacos-- super good. Hit all the right tastebuds. Salty, sweet, crunchy and fresh. 
Entree-my boyfriend got the beef Wellington which he really enjoyed. It also came with bone marrow. I got the Arctic char which was also lovely. 

Would love to try their rotisserie to go!
author: Katlyn H.

description:
Loved this place for date night. The food was great! I got the Gem Salad and the 1/2 Rotisserie Chicken. My husband got the Beef Filet Wellington and Potatoes Gratin. We both decided next time we'd split the whole chicken and get another side. 
Just enough ambience and noise with the ability to still carry on a conversation. 
We saw 2 larger groups (6+) and they were a tight fit and needed reservations, but the server was on-it for both of the tables.
author: Susan H.

description: This review is for my second visit. I made the reservation on yelp on day of the dinner. The atmosphere was intimate and cozy. I recommend their famous chicken that comes with a side that you can choose. Service was excellent and very attentive.
author: rod h.

description:
The charm that this intimate, French restaurant exudes, was captivating.  

Dimly lit setting and warm ambiance to the entirety of this place. Lovely.

It seems like they change up their Hors D'oeuvre dishes quite frequently.  Ordered up the lobster salad as a delectable starter. 

Wine selections are of abundance.  I'd say go with the French since it is a French restaurant after all.

Beef Wellington as a renowned entree here, was a tad bit on the dry side.  There's the au jus that helps and the side bone marrow, complimented well with the savory puff pastry.

To sweeten the finishing course, the golden delicious Apple Tart Tatin, made the perfect mark as a dessert.  

It's a pleasant French restaurant tucked in the neighborhood of Nob Hill.  It was quaint and called to slow down one's pace. 

Enjoyable scene for a wine and dine here.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Came here last Saturday night to finally cross off beef wellington on my food bucket list!

Atmosphere: Perfect for family and date night. The place is small though so be sure to make reservation. They do have bar seating.

Service: Friendly and attentive. The bartender introduced himself as part bartender/part server/part manager. He checked in on us every 10 minutes or so to make sure we had everything we need.

The food:
They've a happy hour menu which ends at 6:30PM. Unfortunately, I forgot to take a picture of it.

- $7 Happy Hour Mussels: Sooo delicious! The garlic butter sauce was top-notched and the portion is generous for $7 as well.  Highly recommended!

- Happy Hour Calamari: Forgot about the price but I think it was either $7 or $8. Love the crispiness of it!

- Beef Wellington: Comes with bone marrow! It did not disappoint! It was served on a hot plate and I love it when my steak is serve on a hot plate. The steak was nice, tender, and juicy. The maitake mushroom compliments the steak well. And the puff pastry wrapped the whole thing up like a warm, flaky, savory little blanket. The bone marrow adds a nice saltiness to the dish. The chicken jus sauce on the side was a little strong for my taste so I hardly dip my steak in. My steak was a little overcooked though; I asked for medium rare and I think it was more like medium. Not a deal breaker as it was still delicious and juicy. Overall, I loved it and was glad I was able to cross it off my food bucket list.

- Banana Creme Brulee - One of my favorite creme brulee ever! Very unique. The banana adds a nice flavor and I think it cuts down on the sweetness of the dessert. Recommended.

Overall, it was a nice place to have a delicious dinner with your best friend or family on a Saturday night. :)
author: Lisa K.

description:
I am so happy I found this cute little cosy place. It's a gem.
I am French myself, when I go there it feels like home , the food is amazing and the service is great. 
My wife had the beef Wellington which was amazing, I tried the chicken rotisserie with some sides which I definitely recommend . 
Our server was always very attentive plus they have a really nice selection of wine. 
We ll be back for sure.
author: Pierrot R.

description:
Dinner review. 

Beef Tartare & Foie gras tacos - 4/5
Chicken liver Parfait - 3/5
Potato goat cheese gratin - 3/5
Beef Filet wellington - 4/5
Osso bucco - 2/5
Banana creme brulee - 3/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
I will preface by saying that the incredibly disappointing experience I had at Cocotte last night has led me to write my first Yelp review ever.

I am not quite sure who was in charge of the restaurant, because it felt like no one. First off, my 3 girlfriends and I had a 7:45pm reservation for a birthday dinner - it took 30 minutes to be seated with no apology as we were continuously being shooed around the tiny entry way of the restaurant. Second off, the waiter told us to order WAY more food than was necessary for the table, so we were left having to waste so much food and money at the end of the meal. Thirdly, it took 4 requests to get any water, and 20 minutes to get more toasted bread after asking multiple restaurant staff members. The table next to us (and all tables around us) sat down after and left before we were served any food. 

The food itself was delicious, however the disgusting service has made me never want to return nor recommend the restaurant to any of my friends in the neighborhood. 

The most challenging part was that after complaining, no restaurant staff offered to comp any part of the meal, bring a dessert for the birthday girl, or even apologize for that matter. I only received a blanket excuse of "this is how we do things in Europe." 

Safe to say I will not be returning and recommend my fellow SF neighbors the same.
author: Claire H.

description:
Went here for my birthday with my best pal - we went early and found parking. Tough area to find parking- the trolley runs through here too. 

We sat down on a Saturday evening, the small room was mostly full and filling up while we started. It's a cool ambience - the front is open to the sidewalk and there's a compact but well put together bar on the right as you walk in. My friend brought in a bottle of Parador Reserve Tempranillo - and older vintage that was drinking perfectly. The waiter came over and opened the bottle. He was a very tall waiter, good attitude and said he made wine. They were pouring the Barbera and Grenache '11 at the restaurant. So we tried a glass of each. He admitted they didn't look great - they didn't and they we're just okay. Tasted like the wine of the day that they're getting rid of - or maybe use it in the Coq au vin. I suggested he taste our wine and he poured himself a full glass - which in my opinion was too much. You always let the customer pour how much, but okay let's eat. 

We split an order of the Mussels and we both thought they were excellent. I wouldn't call it abundant but a good portion. The sauce was outstanding and required drenching their small baguettes into it for full enjoyment. The bread was good - slightly crusty in the best way. 
Mussels Mariniere $13,00 White wine, shallots, garlic, parsley, salted butter. And we had the French Fries with it that were quite good. 

My friend then had the Beef Wellington (done perfectly) $33 and I had the Duck Breast special I think was $28. We also had some white wine by the glass. Overall a great experience - service was good, staff was friendly and on top of water, bread, plates - not too soon or too late. Friendly and appropriate. 

The one thing that bothered me was the waiter selling us his wine that sucked, then pouring a whole glass of our expensive bottle and then charging us the full corkage of $20 bucks. That was bullshit - but maybe like his wine he's uneducated in how you deal with those situations. I asked him to take it off and he took off $7.50 cents. Which was insulting after such a great experience - you're going to let us leave with this bad taste of your wine. Oh well - do check it out. Good food and service.
author: Rew C.

description:
The food was pretty okay, however I was disappointed with the service and the way I felt after leaving the restaurant. My fiancé and I went to celebrate Valentine's Day and had a 9:15 pm reservation. When we got there around 9:10 or so, we weren't attended by the hostess for about 10 minutes or more, until we literally sought her attention. Post that we hung out by the bar and waited for another 20 minutes or so to be seated. The drinks at the bar were great, unique and fun. We enjoyed the cable car and summer in Spain. 

When we got to ordering dinner, I was bummed to know they didn't have the dish I had been looking forward to all week - The Beef entree. The menu moreover didn't have other alternative meat options for entrees and we ordered the remaining two dishes on the menu. I was bummed but okay until I noticed the person right next to us who ordered the beef entree *after* us and the chef managed to get him the "last serving" they had. That was disappointing and I also expressed my feelings to the server, who tried making our meal better with added truffles. 

Overall I kinda enjoyed the ambience, and the food flavors were interesting too. The Bathroom is a mess, and you need to walk to it via the kitchen and and its unclear as to where it is. For a restaurant as expensive as this, I would expect a better Bathroom & experience. Very Overpriced for sure - my fiancé who doesn't considers the price we pay while judging an experience also thought it was overpriced. Probably having the beef or alternate meat options would have made me feel slightly better.
author: Zaina H.

description: Service is quite mediocre considering the prices they charge, and is especially unacceptable when you consider that they also automatically include a 4% surcharge to every bill. Servers aren't paying attention to your table so it's annoying to have to constantly be trying to get their attention for basic things such as 1) when you want to order and 2) when there is no water/bread for the table after sitting down for more than 20 minutes. The restaurant is also tiny and extremely loud which makes it difficult to have a conversation. If you're looking for a nice date night or special occasion, definitely stay away as this place does not have the right ambiance or vibe for it.
author: Sarah C.

description: Came for NYE dinner and all the food was delicious. Prix fixe dinner which isn't always my favorite but I was pleasantly surprised. The ambiance is beautiful, dim lighting, open but intimate at the same time. My husband had the fois gras two was to start followed by the beef Wellington. I had the goat cheese "beignets" and the rack of lamb. The fois gras stole the show in my opinion and I cursed myself for not ordering it. Had I not tried it I would have been plenty happy with my "beignets" though. Both meats were cooked perfectly and were well-flavored. For dessert I had the white chocolate napoleon and my husband had the banana creme brûlée. We finished off every possible bite of food. Beautiful meal.
author: Sharlene S.

description: Simply amazing in every way.  By far the best Beef Wellington I have ever had, and it's not close, the bone marrow paired with the steak is indescribably delicious.  While this is not a large place by any stretch, service was refined and top notch.  Dessert was another home run... the Banana Creme Brûlée is crazy good - a huge step up from an always scrumptious favorite.  My wife and I had an unforgettable anniversary experience that we will treasure for years.  Despite a fairly high price tag, we WILL be back!
author: Brandon S.

description:
I had the beef Wellington for dinner. It was delicious. In fact everything we ordered was amazing!!  I had a cheese platter for an appetizer. It was served with a strawberry type jam. Paired with the cheese, the strawberry was a welcomed complement. I had the mache salad that surprised me with a warm goat cheese ball that melted in my mouth. The banana creme brûlée ended the meal in the most fabulous way. 

I must add everyone was so nice and thoughtful. 

Make sure you get reservations. We went on a Tuesday night and it was packed.
author: Michelle G.

description: Service and food was outstanding! So fresh, tasty and elegantly presented! You want to eat at this French Restaurant!
author: Amy C.

description: Fantastic food, friendly staff, charming atmosphere. I don't know what they're doing with their chickens, but boy, are they good! If we lived in that neighborhood, we'd be regulars for sure!
author: Joey K.

description: Came here for dinner with the wife on a Saturday night around 7, easily got a table for two without a reservation. Great neighborhood French food. The squash blossoms were exceptional. The chicken cocq au vin was also really, really good. Cosy atmosphere with friendly wait staff. Will definitely return!
author: Marcel C.

description: Today, we decided to celebrate my son's birthday at this restaurant. We were very impressed not only with the taste of all the dishes that we ordered,  but more important the great customer service of Juri, our waiter, and Daniel, the chef that event came to our table to great us. You would enjoy this place.
author: Joaquin V.

description: Definitely will return next time I am in San Francisco.  While I was here with friends, I would recommend this for a romantic evening.  It is dimly lit and quite cozy. The wait staff and the chef were gracious and the food was excellent.
author: aLYSSA k.

description:
What a disappointment our attempted visit to Cocotte was. We had reserved a table for tonight and had written in the notes that we were both using wheelchairs. Cocotte was not described as inaccessible to wheelchairs and we also never heard from the restaurant before we arrived. Only then did we learn that they have a step to get in which was too high for our heavy electric chairs to overcome. My partner had visited the restaurant many years ago and they then had a little portable ramp to help but this time they stated they did not have a ramp. When we expressed how disappointed we were that we had come all the way on public buses, the person we talked to, probably the manager, stated that "well I can't do anything about this and I cannot lie myself down for you to roll in." I pointed out that this was the rather unnecessary and mean comment and he just turned away and left us standing outside of his restaurant.
It is hard to understand why somebody who is working in the hospitality industry has such little adeptness at making people feel taken care off, especially if their establishment made a mistake. But rather than trying to somehow make the situation better, this particular person added insult to injury. I'm now actually glad we couldn't enter the restaurant and didn't contribute to their business considering how their attitude toward accessibility as well as hospitality is.
We then crossed the street and were lucky to get a table at "Seven Hills" where we received exceptional service and wonderful food. We have reviewed them in the past and a review for this experience will follow soon as well.
author: Ursula S.

description: The best thing about this place: when they open up their glass doors when the weather is warm. It is the best warm weather sticky feeling ever. Love the vibe. Nothing in there (including there wonderful food and amazing wine) can compete with the amazing vibes that they have. It is a Neighborhood, weeknight delight.
author: Mary N.

description:
Hubby made reservations for Valentine's Day.  It was a 3 course, $85 prix fixed menu with 3 selections each for appetizer and entree and 2 for dessert.  It's a small place with about 35 seats. They had called a couple weeks earlier to confirm and asked for a credit card to hold the reservation and if you canceled 1 week prior, they will charge your account. For that inflexibility of rules and asking for my credit card info, I wouldn't go back. 

The couple next to us sat in this tiny space with a slanted ceiling more fitted for little people. He was a big guy in girth and height and because tables were packed together like sardines, he had a hard time getting out.  

My Foie Gras was meltingly smooth. It was a large disc which came with thin slices of bread. Hubby had the lobster. Some chunks of lobster which he said was too dry and served in a small cast iron pan.  

We both had the beef Wellington. It was OK. The puff pastry was good. It arrived with some Vegts and the beef was sliced in half.  We couldn't finish the other half and took it home.  

The banana crime brûlée was better than Hubby's dessert. The server even messed up on delivering one of the dishes and the place wasn't full to capacity yet, around 6:30PM.  A health tax is auto added to the bill. Hubby had a glass of French red wine and the bill came to over $200. We were lucky to find street parking.  A nice neighborhood place which he heard about on Bay Area Check Please on TV. We made the reservations on Open Table and if they require a credit card to hold, it should be posted on Open Table not after you've made the reservations.
author: Ry T.

description: Went here for a quick drink after dinner at a local restaurant. Sat at the bar to have a drink, which they said was fine to do. Then got pushed out after the wine was empty because "people were waiting". It was super close to our hotel, but we never went back again.
author: Alexis M.

description: The most AMAZING beef Wellington I have ever had. Great service, really nice and happy staff- energy was great. Wine was delicious
author: Brittany R.

description:
Disappointed. Haterade reviews mentioned natty & possibly drugged-out service. So you KNOW I came to see the real illnana tweaked out twerked out d.r.a.m.a. drama. But each employee interaction I had was polite & shizz. Eff that.

Yeah the name and *some* menu items are French, but don't get caught up - my meal was more British x Mexican x Japanese x Southern if anything. Plus waitress adopted my slang (amusing), and they played a jazz song sampled by A Tribe Called Quest.

(^_^) Beef Filet Wellington $33
Traded my Will & Kate fridge for this.

(^_^) Beef Tartar & Foie Gras Tacos $14
Gawd yes.

(^_^) Broccoli Di Ciccio $6
Tempura w Hail Caesar dressing.

(^_^) Iced Tea $4
Duh.

Zut zut et zut! Je me souviens. Je reviendrai mzafzas. Sahdahtay...
author: Dan B.

description:
Over the years, I've become better at budgeting. I've gotten so good at it that I can now afford to spend money on a wonderful dinner on a random Tuesday evening. (kidding, I'm in denial. I don't look at my credit card statements!)

I'm even more fortunate to have eager yelp friends who respond with an excited "YES!" when I send an invite out. That's what (yelp) friends are for, right?

Cocotte popped up on the search for a cute restaurant in the Nob Hill area. The cable car tracks are right outside, it's frequented by locals and it's the opposite of trendy! I like that. It's a very welcoming neighborhood space. 

We enjoyed a feast of rustic French fare. From moules marinieres (tantalizing broth and plump mussels!), exquisite rotisserie chicken, mouth watering beef wellington with indulgent bone marrow, luxurious foie gras, a massive butcher cut pork chop and other tasty options. We also ordered several desserts. I mean, when you go out with yelpers, you go all OUT. 

I'm a die hard fan of duck and it's pretty much a given I'll order it 99.9% of the time when I'm at a French restaurant. The duck leg confit here has just the right amount of salty, crispy skin with moist MMMeat served over farro pilaf, freshened with spring onions and watercress; drizzled with blood orange au jus. Superb! I don't duck around when it comes to duck, that's foie sure! ;-)

I hope to return to the warm loving embrace that is Cocotte. You should also put this on your list if you're craving for rotisserie in a non-fussy environment. Bon appetit!
author: Janice C.

description:
Amazing service, great wine selection, casual but refined French-California cuisine...

Everything was tasty! We'll be back!
author: Evan A.

description:
My friend and I have been craving beef Wellington for so long but we hard such a hard time finding a restaurant that serves it. We finally got the chance to come and try it here and it was the best. The beef was cooked perfectly medium-rare and the filling was delicious.

We also ordered the Coq au Vin and the Mussels mariniere. The mussels were really plump and were cooked in a garlic butter sauce. The coq au vin was great as well; the chicken was very tender and the wine sauce was delicious.
author: Lu Y.

description:
Ate here on a recent Saturday night. We made a reservation for 8p and late the night prior were notified that the restaurant cancelled the reservation. Call restaurant to find out what happened, they claim to have not done anything, are unapologetic and reschedule us for 8:30p. So we arrive around 8:25p, check in and proceed to wait for another 20-30 minutes to be seated. If you don't mind waiting for a long time for your reservation to be honored, enjoy loud and crowded places, and bland/stale quality food (I ordered the bouillabaisse and besides being a small portion it tasted like it would've been fresh the weekend prior), then this is the place for you. Otherwise, would recommend to steer clear.

Acoustics: Subpar
Service: Poor/Unfriendly
Food Quality: Bland and Stale
author: Max F.

description: Best chicken I've ever had! Incredible service and atmosphere. Every sauce was to die for and the dessert was heavenly. Chef introduced himself to us and that really was the cherry on top. We're excited about our new neighborhood spot--will definitely return!!
author: Devon B.

description: Place is a cozy neighborhood spot. Wine selection was strong, and cocktails looked tempting, but unfortunately, the bartender was not there so we had to stick to wine and beer. Service was friendly but slow. Coq au vin and beef wellington were delicious. Fries were so so.
author: Robyn B.

description:
Ordered through Uber Eats. After 90 mins I get a call from Uber saying the restaurant claims someone else picked up the order. 
I can only assume the most abysmal execution of basic restaurant services for food pickup. 
I cannot recommend or condone this.
author: Subho C.

description:
Cocotte is the place to go for beef wellington! With a hearty amount and some bone marrow on the side it will be delicious, cooked to perfection, and overall... amazing! The space is a little cramped and the price is high, but the quality of food and speed of service are worth it. The waiter was a little pretentious, since we decided to share plates instead of each ordering our own, but the explanation of dishes was impeccable and the sangria is awesome to start the meal was a plus! Not a place to go all the time, but good for a cozy date night treat. (also get ready to circle forever for parking, it is not a very open area, but hey, it's SF!) 
Also, I ordered the calamari thinking it was fried, and when I found out it wasn't and tried to change my order it was "too late" and a few minutes later the plate came to my seat. With the fried calamari at happy hour and french-style during dinner be careful!
author: Tooka Z.

description:
Thanks to Janice C, I finally had dinner at Cocotte on Tuesday, November 24th at 7:30pm. Janice made a reservation for 5 people via OpenTable a couple weeks prior.

Starters:
*Meat platter: bressola (cured beef), duck salami sausage, local dry coppa, chicken liver terrine, grain mustard, pickled vegetables, walnut & raisin toast ($18)
*Beef tartar & foie gras tacos: hand-cut beef tartar, capers, cornichons, shallots, grated foie gras, pickled red onion, crema fresca ($14) x2
*Mussels marinieres: lemon, white wine, salted butter, shallot ($13)
*Duck foie gras mi-cuit: poached red wine bartlett pear, toasted house made brioche ($22)

I'm a huge charcuterie fan, so I loved the meat platter. The mussels were plump and the sauce delish! I haven't had foie in a while, so mi-cuit was a treat! The tacos didn't have much foie flavor, but I do love crunchy tacos so this was a nice play on beef tartar.

Mains and Les Cocottes:
*Organic Petaluma chicken rotisserie served with romesco sauce, arugula pesto, creamy porcini sauce accompanied by a cocotte of your choice: Cauliflower & espelette pepper gratin ($32 whole chicken)
*Beef wellington: maitake mushrooms, veal jus, bone marrow, breadcrumbs ($33)
*Duck leg confit: oven farro pilaf, spring onion, blood orange gastrique jus, living watercress ($24)
*Butcher cut: Pork ($28)
*Spinach: golden raisins, garlic apple cider ($7)
*Hand-cut french fries: lemon aioli ($7)
*Cocotte of the day: Brussels sprouts ($7)

I adored the special which was pork. I love a nicely cooked piece of pig. Mmmmm... meat! The duck was deliciously tender. I wasn't sure if I'd like the beef wellington due to the puff pastry, but surprisely, I did. And that piece of bone marrow? Sooo good! I'd skip the chicken next time as it was super dry and overcooked. At least the breast piece I tried to eat was. My favorite cocotte was the cauliflower gratin. And I don't even really like cauliflower. It was deliciously creamy. Like potatoes au gratin. I love spinach, but I wasn't a huge fan of the raisins. My least favorite cocotte was the brussels. They were a little undercooked and needed more oomph. They just tasted like cooked brussels which I found kind of boring.

Desserts:
*Banana creme brulee ($7)
*Profiterolles: marsalla raisin ice cream, almonds, chocolate sauce ($7)

Must have dessert is the banana brulee. Although the bananas keep it from having that hard sugary crust, I adore banana desserts and a good creme brulee, so this married the two well. I'm not a huge chocolate person so I only had a bite or so of the profiterolles. Everyone in my party enjoyed them though.

Drinks:
*Chateau respide-medeville graves '11, Bordeaux, France ($55)
*City cellars ($15 glass)
*Pied a terre cab ($15 glass)
*Porto ($14 glass) ×2
*Muscat ($14 glass)

What's dinner without drinks?! I told the server I wanted a good red that was moderately price. Told him I'm a cab girl and he suggested the Graves. This worked great for our party! I also had a follow up glass of wine that he suggested as well. I believe it was the Pied a terre cab though. I actually enjoyed that glass more as it was a bolder red.

Cocotte has a charming neighborhood restaurant feel to it. A great place to have dinner with a wonderful group of friends.

Note: Remember to check your bill to see if they added gratuity to it already. We were a party of 5 and they added an automatic 20% gratuity. (I always thought this only happened to parties of 6 or more. I guess every restaurant is different.) I'm glad we noticed or else we may have tipped on top of that.
author: Elena N.

description:
Valentine's Dinner Date 2017 (not on Valentine's Day on Tuesday, but that Thursday). Reservation was for 6:30 pm. 

Food is good. Mussel appetizer in a tomato and ausage bisuqe/soup served with bread for dipping (Favorite dish of the night). Beef wellington with bone marrow (Average). Fries for $7 (Average). Banana creme brulee for $7.50 (Unique). 

Small dining establishment with small candles on each dining table. Tables are too close to one another. Bar area by the entrance. Dim lighting. 

Waiter was slow to refill water :/. I completely ran dry at one point.
author: Fanny T.

description:
The short story- We would not dine here again. $190 and I am not sure what for. Everything started out ok but got worse the longer we were there. The restaurant got louder and louder until we couldn't converse. Our entrees took an hour and came overcooked. Service was ok but for what we paid we should not have gone without plates and silverware for our appetizer. No spoon for the bone marrow. No real attention to detail as far as table service. We don't mind dropping money on good food and service but we felt cheated here.

The long story-
Bread was tasty and warm and served with a healthy amount of real butter. Off to a good start!

Duck empanadas were just ok, meat was a bit dry.
 
The fries were just fries and did not dictate an $8 price tag, though the lemon aoli they came with was quite nice. 

The Brussels sprouts were overcooked, a bit soggy and did not have any real flavor or texture. Mind you, none of these sides came with the entrees. $9.

The beef wellington was ok, but not amazing and was $32 with no sides. It did come with a marrow bone which was prepared well but was only about a half tablespoon of marrow in it. The meat was ordered medium, was served well.

The half chicken looked pleasing enough. $22, no sides. Served with 3 sauces. The cilantro pesto was very lovely, porcini sauce just alright and the 3rd sauce was a lackluster mystery. Our server didn't bother to tell us about the sauces. Chicken was overcooked, a bit dry and not particularly flavorful. Honestly, the Costco chickens surpass these easily.

The creme brûlée was the worst I have ever had, think jello banana pudding. There were cold spots throughout and no crunch on top. This was possibly the most disappointing failure in the meal.

Wine was spectacular. No complaints here. $45 bottle. Good to the last drop.


The restaurant itself is cute enough, dim lighting, candles. Why the hell are we listening to Outkast? I like Outkast but it sets the wrong tone. Small. There are too many damn tables in here. We had to physically move our table to let other patrons pass by. This is unacceptable. The waiter bumped my husband with his ass every time he went to serve the corner table. This is so freaking not kosher. Take out a few tables and give better service and food. The kitchen is obviously unable to keep up, our food took over an hour.

Finally, the place doesn't look very clean when you go back to use the restroom. Very dusty. The toilet seat is hanging onto the toilet by a thread. Why on Earth would a place where an average p/p dinner tab is at least $50 not by a suitable toilet seat. The bathroom itself was covered in dust and paper towels littered everywhere. Seeing what we spent here, using the bathroom should not have made me feel like I was in a dive bar in the TL.

I simply can not fathom how this place has a 4 star rating. For the cost there are so many exceptional restaurants in this city.
author: Disco B.

description: Cocotte came highly recommended. I found it fair to midland as we say in the Scottish Highlands. Service was impeccable, but I found the menu uninspiring and a bit vague in its attempt.
author: Gaijin S.

description: It's been a few months since I went to Cocotte, but the impression it made left such an impact, that I find myself needing to write a review. My husband is allergic to (cow) dairy and I'm gluten-intolerant, so finding a restaurant where we can both enjoy the food is something of a novelty. My husband had the beef wellington, which was on his bucket list, and honestly one of the primary reasons we chose to eat here. The food and the service here were excellent!
author: Bethany N.

description:
Oh My God !!! (OMG),
Wish I had time alike Lisa above that gave Four Stars and a great long(er)review...

One Word...

FANTASTIQUE !

Bien

Merci Mikael Audry and to your Grandpapa!

WOW
author: Dave H.

description:
i decided to treat my boyfriend out in celebration of his work promotion. the restaurant is small with outdoor seating as well. seems to be a popular spot so we made reservations ahead of time. the ambiance is pretty romantic, with dim lighting, and a candle on each table. it was my first time seeing a couple holding hands across the table while waiting for their meals. usually i would see that happen in movies haha. the staff were friendly and the service was excellent. i like how the front of the restaurant is completely open. we barely felt the breeze from the wind from sitting inside the restaurant on a warm night. 

me being a germophobe that i am, it has always bothered me that french & italian restaurants like to put their utensils on the table and not on a napkin. i felt unease about using my utensils after our waiter had placed our new set of utensils on the table because i don't think tables are that clean.

Duck foie gras (4/5): this is my first time having foie gras, so it was an interesting experience. but i did enjoy the duck foie gras
Coq au vin (4/5): the meat was good, but i liked the potatoes the best
Pork belly (4/5): the pork belly was delicious, but we didn't like the cauliflower couscous. it tasted funny to us.
Golden delicious apple tart tatin (4/5): the apple tart was really sweet but delicious

notes: the restaurant gets really busy, so come early or make reservations! they offer sparkling water if you don't want to drive tap water. parking is terrible, but you might get lucky.  the portion sizes are small. i was content after eating half of everything with my boyfriend haha. i just have a big appetite.
author: Sylvia H.

description: The food was fantastic. The Restaurant Week menu was a hit and each dish was fantastic. I was not impressed with our waiter. After 1 hour and 29 minutes at the restaurant while still enjoying the remainder of our wine he asked if we would like to have a glass of bubbles at the bar. We were rushed out of our seats much to quickly.
author: Kylie P.

description: Went here with family to celebrate and was expecting some amazing food and service considering the price but was disappointed with the rude and pushy waiter/host. Most of our party got there before our reservation time and was waiting for one last person, who was a sommalier and our resident foodie, and told the waiter this when asked if we're like to order. Instead of accepting our response, he kept coming back pushing for us to order something before the last person arrived. Normally, I would understand if there was a line of people waiting but the place only had one couple in there and no one else. He also kept pushing us to order more and insisted that the food we ordered was not enough. We didn't listen and we STILL ended up with 4 boxes to bring home!
author: Johanna S.

description: Christmas Eve 2017 Dinner could not have been any better!  Perfect table in the alcove, attentive and personable service and EVERYTHING on the pix fixe menu was delicious. Truly a special evening in the city.
author: C K.

description:
We had a nice dinner here last week. The atmosphere is cozy with tight seating and definitely feels like you could be in Paris. 

The service was excellent and attentive.

We ordered and split the rotisserie chicken (delicious), French fries (obviously delicious), potatoes and spinach which were both also quite good.

The potato leek soup on the menu that evening was also one of the better soups I have had in a long time.

This is definitely a good spot for a nice night out!
author: Derek S.

description:
We came to this restaurant for dinner with another couple recently. While the food was OK - neither terrible nor memorable, the service was truly awful and downright rude.

The two things we will remember from this restaurant were that, first, a waiter gave us a nasty look when one of us ordered a salad for a main dish and literally asked, "That's it?" I'm sorry, but a waiter who shames someone like this at dinner simply has no class, and neither does a restaurant that allows this. And secondly, as our dinner came to a close, he told us that people were waiting for our table and that we had to leave. This was RIGHT after we told him we didn't want dessert. So, he immediately came to us with the check, without our solicitation, to kick us out. Now, it's not that we tried to skimp on our dinner or linger too long - we had multiple glasses of wine and had very hearty dinners and it must have taken over an hour and 15 minutes or so. But apparently the waiter must not have cared to provide a modicum of decent service because they had already added a 20% tip automatically to the bill for a party of 4. 

Avoid this place; there are simply way too many good restaurants in this area with polite and nice employees to waste time here.
author: Sylvia K.

description: People from outta town often ask me for a nice romantic San Franciscan spot that serves tasty food. Cocotte always seems to come to mind. The place is located on the iconic cable car Hyde Street (which is as SF as it gets) and offers up some of the tastiest food. Very friendly and attentive service and a beautiful, quaint, and charming little venue. I would recommend making reservations as it can fill up pretty fast.
author: Gordon Z.

description: We had the thanksgiving menu. It was amazing and delicious. Food and service were amazing! Cute French spot, must check out.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Listen up Lovies, 

1) You must get the Duck Platter. 
2) Indulge on their delicious BANANA CREME BRULEE.
3) Enjoy a class of wine.

I've had good meals at Cocotte in the past. Each time I'm back to visit, they never disappoint. 

Great value, great portions, excellent food, and friendly attentive staff. This can be a great date night place and it quite cute too!  The only downside about this place is the location, so hard to find parking. Other than that, I'm a fan. 

I hope you give this quaint place a try. Cheers!

The simple things in life.
author: Owie N.

description:
This is a cute spot for date night! 

My husband and I went here because we scored reservations for Restaurant Week here in SF. We are not too familiar with French cuisine, however we were open to trying new things. 

Our hostess sat us in the BEST table of the restaurant, which was this converted jacket closet made into it's own dining cove for 2 people. Folks who were sitting by us were scoping us out as it was decorated in a way to allow for privacy, but with elegant decor.

Unfortunately, I was not feeling well that day, so my husband mainly had to enjoy his and part of my dinner while I watched. However, I would definitely be open to heading out here again in the near future as the service and ambiance was amazing!
author: Tracy C.

description: Learned about Cocotte from Check Please.  Went last night, it was a lovely experience.  Food (had the roasted chicken, beef wellington, squash, and potato gratin) fantastic, dessert (banana creme brulee), wine amazing.  Loved everything about this place.  Staff was really nice/cheerful, so glad we went, will be back!
author: Kate P.

description: Where do I begin... We chose to sit at the bar and that was the beginning of the best decision of the night. Juri the manager is absolutely amazing! We drank amazing beverages, recommend starting with the Kir Royal.  We decided to share the beef Wellington, potatoes cheese gratin and spinach and wow, all were phenomenal! Wherever you are staying in San Francisco it is worth the drive or walk to visit this restaurant!
author: Kristie A.

description: Nice atmosphere. The squash appetizer was interesting, but the coq au vin entrée was nothing special.
author: Frank M.

description: Cute and cozy ambiance, decent food especially the beef wellington. The octopus was fresh and nice too. I'd say the food is 4 star But they took about 30 minutes to seat us despite having a reservation, and i wasn't impressed with sides and dessert. We were excited about the patio gratin but it was ok.
author: Shirin E.

description:
Truly disappointed. I'd say it felt even worse, because one of my favorite SF restaurants is just across the street. That being said, the food and price point was one of the most disappointing SF experiences I've had to date. The friendly staff and beautiful location is all great, but then I had the food and I was just sorely sorely disappointed like I haven't been in a long time.

I had the Coq Au Vin (a French classic) as well as the butcher's cut which ended up being the Restaurant week featured Pork Shank Osso Bucco. Wow, maybe they were too busy for their Restaurant week clientele, but the food came so bland, undercooked, and a hot mess. For the price point of $20+ a dish, with a couple of glasses of wine, I really felt like I had been robbed  with my experience tonight. 

The Coq Au Vin felt anything but slowly cooked in wine, pancetta, carrots with the hen. It was seriously viscous and bland that felt like it was rushed together. 

As for the osso bucco, I know pork is usually dry and blander, but wow it was also just rushed and bland. I think the fact it was featured in the Restaurant week portion just meant a lot of quantity and little quality. The kale and polenta was sadly the most prominent feature of this dish. When it came to the pork and natural jus, it was jus disappointing (haha apologies for the pun).

Anyways, considering the plethora of quality French restaurants in SF, I'm sad to say Cocotte will not be one I visit again.
author: Joseph L.

description:
Went here for a relatively large group and had a terrible experience. The waitstaff for the most part was very friendly, however the waiter/host was extremely rude and not hospitable.

A few examples:
When we were ordering wine, the few we wanted were out and instead of explaining that they were out due to popularity or flavor profile he simply said "Those are the cheapest bottles we carry." We ended up just opening two bottles of our own wine after he said corkage was $20.00 per bottle. 
We ordered the frisee salad which had persimmons as a garnish and NO pomegranate. When the salad came it had pomegranate, but no persimmons. When we asked him if we got the right salad he said "Oh that's a garnish, but you see the frisee, that's frissee." We had to ask another waiter who then took the salad and just got persimmon shavings on top.
When the bill finally came we were looking over it and "by mistake" he hit the corkage as $25.00 per bottle. When we asked him he said "Oh yeah that was a mistake, the buttons are right next to each other." I don't know what kind of honest establishment wouldn't tell you that a button was mistakenly until you had to point it out. I would like to give him the benefit of the doubt but given his attitude in the above two examples it seems more intentional.

The food was mediocre and at the price point and service I would definitely not go back again.
author: Cliff C.

description: Love everything about this place. The location with the cute cable cars outside, the ambiance and decor, friendly staff and of course amazing French food! Been here 2x now and been super happy and pleased everytime. The quality is great!
author: Jo L.

description: Excellent food and service! Celebrated a birthday and it was so special for my friend!
author: Teresa J.

description: OK...not now does the full Monty. Dined tonight. Soooo awesome. Will update this review soon.
author: S L.

description:
Me and my bestie just looking for good food in SF. 
WOW! Great food. The wine selection was very nice. THE Mussels...yuummm,
And if you like beef wellington..forget Chef Ramseys, this was WAYYY BETTER. SOOO GOOD! Not over priced. Just right!  Im going back for sure!
author: shirley c.

description:
The mister brought me here for my birthday (which coincided with Thanksgiving) and we had the three course prix fix dinner. The food was simply amazing! I had foi gras (which was on my bucket list - I wanted to try it at least once. And it was soooo gooood). It was a huge portion for an appetizer. Super creamy, very filling, too. With roasted bread and cumquats. Then beef Wellington for the main course. Awesome beef, super tender, little pink in the middle. It came with gratineed potato and parsnip (?). I opted for the added truffle ($20) on the beef, but was a bit disappointed. I had black truffles before and they were amazing, these didn't taste like anything though. Dessert was a banana creme brulee that was simply to die for. We are not big wine drinkers, so no wine for us. I had a special virgin cocktail made for me though, just because. It was very refreshing, because I requested "something with grapefruit". Hail to the barkeeper!

I know Thanksgiving is a special day for the hospitality business, so I only take one star off for the ambiance. Don't get me wrong, the place is cute and on any other day it might be great that it's cozy... but I got bumped into by the waiter every.freaking.time he passed me, because everything was so cramped. And I wasn't able to take of my jacket the entire evening, because the door remained open, although the temperatures were below 50. The wait staff didn't mind of course, they were running around like crazy. The hostess even had a sleeveless dress on. But to eat in this cold was a bit uncomfortable. 
Service in generall was very nice though!

The dinner for two came to $250 with tip and everything. Pretty steep but expected (remember, no alcohol!).
author: Alexa W.

description: For the price, this place is garbage. Meat tasted boiled, tuna tartare was grey. Their creme brulee wasn't even bruled. $14 glass of wine gave me an immediate headache. Host had a very intrusive style, but perhaps that just wasn't my cup of tea. Regardless, charging that much for that quality of food is deserving the 1star.
author: Kevin Y.

description: the food was underseasoned and very dull and the waiter was inattentive.the bus boys were the stars of this restaurant.i will not go back nor will i recommend this place.
author: Sumita N.

description: I really enjoyed this place. The food was great, the wine list was stellar! My only complaint is the music! This is a charming, romantic French restaurant, so why were they playing (at a pretty high volume) new school poppy/hip-hoppy type music?? I know this is small thing but it kind of killed the ambiance! Just a suggestion, play some better music, or at least something you don't notice as much! Other than the music, loved it and will be back!
author: Amya A.

description:
I've got to say i had higher expectations for this place. It's about 3 blocks from my place, had great reviews and i was able to make a last minute reservation on opentable so i was stoked to go there. It's a cute little place, from the outside looks perfect for date night but it was actually really loud inside and was hard for us to hear each other from across the table. 

we started with the salmon crudo because it sounded amazing, but the fish was very salty so it killed the freshness of the salmon & the sauce on the bottom was a little overpowering. It also had fried capers which i love, but made the dish even more salty. for entrees, the chicken was dry and underwhelming.
author: danielle a.

description: Incredible.  Duck Breast and the Wellington were spectacular.   Also highly recommend the Cauliflower gratin.
author: Chris L.

description: Great restaurant with high quality food. The wine selection is good but pricey. It's a relaxed environment in there so not somewhere to go and make too much noise !
author: Ian W.

description:
Reasonably-priced French country cuisine....delicious, hearty Coq Au Vin, but some disappointments too....
The endive/pear salad was very skimpy on the goat cheese, practically non-exixstent...and the portion was petite.  Unimpressive.  I've had better apple tarte tatin with more substantial buttery crust, but this passed satisfactorily. 

But the service was fine, and the ambiance: excellent; cozy.  I might return to try some other items, because their pricing/food is a good value.
author: Brad C.

description: We Loved this romantic bistro. I went with a friend and sat at the bar and the tables were full of couples and friends. Had a great neighborhood vibe and service. Our steak and meat board were both very good. Excellent wine list.
author: Christina W.

description:
Every trip in here it gets better and better. The food is wonderful, full of flavors, great presentation. I love that the menu sticks with the French classics - coq au vin and the roasted chicken with cocottes is always on the menu - but throws in a little variety with rotating dishes. The foie gras is one of my favorites in SF.

But what takes the cake is Yuri, who runs the wine bar (he's the guy with the hair bun, who stylishly manages to pull it off). Yuri is a fantastic local purveyor of wines but is also a wine maker. His new venture, City Cellars, is now featured on the menu as of this year and every bottle I've had, while 2011 vintage and still a bit young, has excellent flavor and will bode well in another year for drinking. They're affordable wines and with the added selection of great French and Spanish wines it's a treat to stop in here all the time to try something new.

And despite my having been here only 3 times and spaced apart by well over 6 months each visit and with different people, he always remembers who I am and makes sure to greet me. I have restaurants I go into every weekend for brunch on Polk St. who don't remember serving me at all. That's one of the main reasons for why the ratings go up for me, aside from supporting wine makers.

The restaurant does run into trouble sometimes with having enough waitstaff on hand, though. But then again, we Americans have a strangeness for expecting fast service and immediate attention and truly, the wait hasn't been that long. But I do observe Yuri spending a lot of time running around to each table for more than just wine recommendations, so if you're sitting at the bar or waiting for a wine selection it might take a few minutes longer. Again, nothing obscene in terms of a long wait, but it does require you to be relaxed, not in a rush and ready to sit in for a good meal.

This is also not a good restaurant for a big dinner party. If you have more than 4 people, skip it.

The best news of all...little tourism comes here. It's all locals. So if you're looking to get away from that Salesforce conference that happens 3x a year, it's a good time to head north.
author: Alita M.

description: Took my mom here for an early weeknight dinner when she came to town, and we were both completely charmed by the atmosphere and service. We ordered the beef wellington and coq au vin and shared both. Each was delicious but the beef wellington really stood out. The wine recommendations were excellent as well. Mom and I both left full and happy, I would definitely dine here again!
author: A G.

description: We sat at the bar and the bartender was very personable. Food was good! Left happy.
author: Rachel T.

description: This is the first zagat listed restaurant who absolutely let us down! Service was slow, quality lacked on all ends, and very pricy for what was offered. The server bawked at us asking for a couple more slices of lemon for our meal. The squash blossom appetizer only has two small pieces to the dish with little flavor or excitement. The beef wellington lacked flavor, bland, flat and the sauce was the same. We wanted brussel sprouts but they were out so we chose spinach which had way too much undercooked pieces of garlic, nothing special to write home about, again. Could taste the lack of love in the food, meal and establishment. No recommendations here, you can skip. Not on any day and especially not on a weekend Friday night.  Hostess was not hospitality minded, no warm or welcome here. Sorry to say, cocotte is not it and if staying on this track, will never be.
author: Kikien B.

description: I've been wanting to visit this cozy neighborhood spot for a long time, and I'm so glad I finally did. I was in the mood for mussels, so my boyfriend and I decided to split those, beef tartare/foie grad tacos and Beef Wellington with a side of spinach. Everything was delicious! The bone marrow with the Beef Wellington might be the best I've had. Next time I will try the rotisserie chicken. It smelled so good too!
author: Kim O.

description:
Came here for our date on Friday night and everything was delicious as usual. I love this restaurant...it always feels so cozy and reminds me of the holidays every time I come here. 

We got the Yukon Potato Gratin, Beef Wellington, Coq au Vin, and Banana Creme Brulee for dessert.

The menu items aren't incredibly creative, but they do their dishes so well. I'd come just for the creme brulee.
author: Bonnie L.

description: Very good! We went there for restaurant week, i had the trout and my husband had mussels~ very nice atmosphere and great meal! The apple tart is ok
author: Katy H.

description: Good beef Wellington but my son wished it was a bigger piece. I loved the chicken but the Spinach had way too much garlic in it! The Manager from  Stinson beach was exceptional because he ran the entire restaurant and handle the bar and all the tables.  Very impressive that he was so informed about each dish and was so pleasant. Music & lighting was super. Wish the food was a little larger for the price.
author: Deborah L.

description:
I have been to cocotte a couple of times before and Iv always had fond memories of this place. However in the past month I feel the food is not as par as it used to be. The menu also has changed. I preferred the previous one. We came with a group of 4.
Among the items which are still good - beef Wellington and the profiteroles 
I was very disappointed with the calamari, empanadas, lava cake and the tartare. They definitely were better before.
author: Nupur S.

description:
I liked Cocotte on a recent Friday night visit and would probably revisit but a few things were not so great. 

First of all I had a sole dish that was way overcooked and oversalted. It was served on a bed of a bunch of other stuff including pickled beets which were inedible (practically raw and impossible to cut with a knife). In all this dish is a fail because the concept is a bit highfalutin' and unnecessary - "seared petrale sole, pickled beets, golden raisins and garlic, lemon yogurt and dill". 

 Best part of my meal were probably the french fries and the few nibbles I had of the duck foie gras. The chocolate cake fondant was dry and not particularly flavorful, other than a little bit of fondant. Wouldn't order that again. 

The thing that made the evening was my great dining companions, but of course it being a Friday the noise level was high so it was more than a little difficult to converse. No surprises there. Service was not exactly attentive but when the restaurant is full I don't know how the wait staff negotiates that room - it's hard to find a path to get through!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Cocotte is hands down my favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco. The food is beyond excellent-- attention is given to every detail, the flavor combinations are supreme, and the scope of the menu is fantastic. The ambiance is beyond reproach, and the service is tailored to make sure that your experience is completely taken care of. 

A single time, my duck was slightly dry, but not to the point that I felt the need to send it back. All in all, Cocotte is amazing. Shoutout in particular to the hostess worked super hard to make sure I got the table that I wanted on my birthday. Thank you!
author: Kat A.

description:
C'est Magnifique!

Alors, mes amies Cocotte est tres romantique. Cocotte has to be one of my favorite restaurants in the entire city of SF. I recently re located from the concrete jungle (SoMa) to Russian Hill in an effort to be more of a native. Reservations were easy to snag via OpenTable.

My friends and I started off with a bottle of white and scallops to share. The waitress kindly suggested her favorites and we told her about our entree selection which made choosing a white super easy. For our main, we ordered Coq Au Vin, potato gratin and the half chicken. Absolutely delicious and the sauce from Coq au vin was the perfect dip for our baguette.

Overall, the restaurant is a bit on the louder side and would be best suited for an intimate dinner or date. The window seating looks very appealing.

I will be back here for sure!
author: Shana B.

description:
Nice place with a view of the trolleys. Dishes tried: butchers cut, half chicken - both a good. 

For my personal preference I would love more paleo friendly choices, but for a French place this is pretty decent.
author: Mike B.

description:
My husband and I had a lovely dinner at Cocotte. Everything - the food, the staff, the ambiance - was on point. I mean, what's more romantic than enjoying a dinner on Hyde Street with the cable cars running by?

Our host/server was friendly, approachable, and ready with good recommendations. And, when we were unsure of the taste of a Bordeaux pinot noir, he was more than kind in explaining the difference between a California and a French pinot. In the end, he was right: the bottle opened up beautifully.

We started with the meat plate, olives, and foie gras. All were good. The olives were plentiful. I had a special, which was pappardelle with rabbit (divine), and my husband had the beef wellington (so good). It was all around a beautiful meal.

The chef came out to introduce himself toward the end, which was nice. I always love a business that shows interest in their customers from all parties!
author: Audrey A.

description: Loved dinner here! The service was so warm and inviting, the location so cozy and romantic, and the food was delicious. Started with the cheese plate and olives, which were each a very good size, and continued with half a rotisserie chicken and coq au vin for entrees, with a potato and goat cheese cocotte. Everything was full of flavor and came with great sauces. Overall, a perfect date night spot.
author: Natalie W.

description:
The restaurant is super cute and romantic, so fantastic ambience for a date.  There's a bar near the front and an assortment of small tables near the back.  

I found our server to be very brusque, at least until she delivered the check at the end at which point she became very friendly.  Given that she seemed to be the only one serving tables, that might also have been part of the problem.  

in any case, my boyfriend ordered the coq au vin, which had a divine flavor and tender chicken.  I ordered the duck leg, and found the flavor to be lacking, as well as the duck to be dry.  Given that there are so many great little French restaurants in SF that do the duck so well (Le Charm, Le P'tit Laurent, Chapeau!), it was pretty disappointing.  

In any case, given the romantic ambience, and the fact that my boyfriend loves this place, I'll chalk it up to bad ordering on my part and hopefully pick better next time!
author: Vivian W.

description: You expect a French bistro in San Francisco to be expensive. Five of us went to Cocotte for a birthday celebration. The wait staff was slow and one even sat at the counter folding napkins when service was needed. Because there are five of us there was an automatic 20% gratuity. And it seemed the waitstaff figured they have that locked in so there was no need to give a lot of service. Three of the five meals were cold when serve to the table. Because it was a birthday we ordered dessert and after 20 minutes we gave up and asked for the check. Of course the desert appeared immediately. As I said it was 20% on food and liquor and then another 4% for the staff healthcare. underwhelmed by the food and we will not return.
author: Charles D.

description: I enjoyed the pork belly and meat platter which was was decent.  My friend didn't like his Gnocchi.  Wasn't too tasty.  Giving this place 3 stars because one of the staff was overly aggressive in trying to get us to order wine/drinks.
author: Thang H.

description:
Food is generally pretty good but service is consistently mediocre to the point of being offensive. Disappointing for a neighborhood spot I still keep going to...
Update is went for a glass of wine and given its hard to screw that up, service was still quite poor just disappointing
author: Jon S.

description: The service here was terrible. Our waiter was extremely pushy and rude. Our table knew what we wanted but the waiter (could have been the owner) was extremely insistent on selling us more. It's a restaurant not a car dealership. In addition to this he constantly hovered around or table and stared at our table throughout our meal. The food was fine but the service was awful. If takeout is an option I would recommend it to avoid the service.
author: Ray E.

description:
If you're a fan of fine French food then Cocotte is a perfect spot for you.  It's a small, romantic spot.  For our meal we had the endive salad, foie gras spread (was my favorite part of the meal), coq a vin and half chicken.  Everything was very tasty and the coq a vin came highly recommended and it met our expectations.

For dessert we got the banana creme brulee and it was executed so well.

Great date night spot in a romantic setting with delicious food.
author: Blake B.

description:
Made a reservation for SF Restaurant Week at 6PM on a Saturday. 
It was relatively empty when we came at 6, there were only about 3 tables seated and a group at the bar area. By 6:30, it was packed! It also seemed like everyone had reservations also. 

We were quickly seated and were given the regular menu, the SFRW menu and the drinks menu. The SFRW menu now reflects their menu posted online!
